div.p: 20. V. Wednesday.

Mr Handy came this morning with a Letter from Mr Daniel Baker, respecting the payment of his Notes to me, and also with a Statement of the Note due to me by the Second Presbyterian Church in this place— I took the latter for examination, and with regard to the former proposed to Mr Handy to advertise for Sale, the House mortgaged to me by Mr Baker, and if he could obtain a purchaser at what it cost Mr Baker, or near it, then to sell the House and pay my debt, retaining the balance of the proceeds at Mr Baker’s disposal— And if he could not sell it thus, and would fix a price at which I might take it, perhaps the debt might be settled in that way. He said he would proceed in that manner, having plenary authority from Mr Baker— Handy spoke of the troublesome controversy into which Mr Campbell has been drawn about Mrs. Eaton— I told I had heard many different accounts of that affair, but none that I could consider as authentic, and I knew not what to believe concerning it. He said that before the inauguration of General Jackson last March Ezra Styles Ely a Presbyterian clergyman of Philadelphia, who had made himself very notorious as a partizan for Jackson, came here to congratulate him upon his triumph— He then saw here Mr Campbell who had been his pupil and intimate friend. In conversing with him about the appointments of Heads of Departments, which were expected. Campbell told him that he hoped Mr Eaton would not as the rumour was be appointed Secretary of War, as it would injure the character of the Administration; and
and then mentioned that Dra physician of Georgetown since deceased had told him of facts discreditable to Mrs Eaton— Mr Ely made no use of this confidential communication at the time— The character of the woman was however so notorious that much opposition was made to the appointment of her husband; which nevertheless took place— In July last however Ely wrote to General Jackson, a statement of what Campbell had communicated to him— Eaton then called upon Campbell for an explanation, and Campbell persisted in the Statement he had made— Mrs Eaton went to Philadelphia, and was closeted with Ely— General Jackson wrote to Ely requesting him to come here— He came, and he and Campbell were both summoned before a Cabinet Meeting, where Campbell persisted in his statements, and was treated with great rudeness by the President— Afterwards Eaton and his wife had another meeting with Campbell; at which Campbell required that another person should be present— Eaton proposed Major Lewis, which Campbell declined, but proposed Coll Towson— At this Meeting Eaton positively denied what had passed between them at a former interview— He since challenged Campbell to fight him— Campbell declined, but proposed meeting him in a Court of Justice— A correspondence ensued in which Eaton’s last Letter threatened Campbell to insult him in the Street— Handy himself is a Clerk in the fourth Auditor’s Office; and he told me of Amos Kendall’s threats to dismiss him because he had published with his name some statement respecting my service and loan to the Presbyterian Church— He concluded however to spare him. And while Kendall was in Kentucky, the Accounts of Timberlake the purser, Mrs Eaton’s first husband were sent to him— Among them were several Letters from Eaton acknowledging the receipt of remittances from him. These remittances have not been credited to Timberlake and he is a large defaulter to the Government.— Handy put the Letters with Timberlake’s accounts into the Hands of Kendall, whence they passed into those of Branch, Secretary of the Navy—of Ingham, Secretary of the Treasury and of the President— They have now been returned to Kendall, and are in his possession— I believe it is excusable in me to know as little of these shameful true libels as possible— Mr Fendall called and introduced Mr Arnold, the petitioner against the election of Pryor Lea— The House have decided in favour of Lea’s election, with a minority of only 20 votes— Mrs Tudor was here in the Evening— Her daughter Mrs Stewart was gone to a party at Mr Berrien’s. She said she was told Mr Webster had presented to the Senate a petition from Mrs Eustis for a pension, to which her husband would if now living be entitled as an Officer of the Army in the Revolutionary War— She heard also that the widow of General Wilkinson had petitioned or would petition— She herself was determined not to petition: and nothing would induce her to change this determination— But she had spoken of it two years ago to Mr Gorham who thought her claim was well founded, and she finally requested if I should see Mr Gorham within a few days, that I would mention it to him, which I promised I would— She said her Son (Frederick) was a young man of so much pride, that if she should petition for a pension and he should be informed of it, he might withhold from her the part of the rent from the Court Street Estate to which she was entitled— Mr Fales of Ohio was also here this Evening— He told me that he had attended my Lectures as an Undergraduate when I was a professor at Cambridge— He said he had attended the Session of the Senate this day, and that Mr Webster and made a very eloquent Speech in answer to attacks upon the Eastern Section of the Union by Benton and Hayne.
21. VI.45. Thursday— Walk after Sun-rise—

It was much to my Surprize broad day-light when I rose this morning, and I began my walk after Sunrise, instead of finishing it as usual before— This affected my occupations for the whole day— I am now reading Solomon’s Song in the third Volume of Scott’s Bible, and The Rhetorics to Herennius in Cicero’s Works— Mr Crowninshield came and introduced two young men from Kentucky by the names of Brown and Scott and Mr Gurley a Dr Martin from Louisiana— R. G. Amory paid me a long morning visit, and talked as usual upon the general state of politics. He has been many years pursuing a claim before Congress, and accommodates his opinions to the doctrines of the Times. He spoke of a conversation that he had last Evening with some persons from South Carolina who were very inquisitive about the consequences of a State’s seceding from the Union. Mr T. B. Johnson was here; and Mrs Frye— Mr Webster was here in the Evening, about half an hour before the Drawing Room at the Presidents— He said there would be a very earnest debate in the Senate upon the President’s nominations; and if it should prove, as he had been assured it would, that L. W. Tazewell one of the Senators from Virginia should not come, some of the nominations would be rejected— It was said to be ascertained that 22 Senators would vote against them— There is one vacancy by the Death of Mr Reed from Mississippi—one by the absence of G. M. Troup of Georgia suddenly called home by some domestic occurrence, and who has obtained leave of absence for the remainder of the Session— 23. Senators administration men remain, and the defection of one of them would turn the scale against the nominations— I told him if this was true the effect would be that they would purchase the attendance of Tazewell, who would sell it upon his own terms— As yet in spite of all their internal dissensions they hold together In party dissensions the profligate league together more closely than the honest for the very reason that individuals have no principle of their own to cling to. I believe that all the nominations of any importance will be confirmed— Mr Webster said he would call upon me again in a few days, as he wished to converse with me upon the Constitutional principles concerning removals from Office— I answered Letters from Mr Quincy President of Harvard University and from John Pierce Secretary to the Board of Overseers; and advised them of my acceptance of a Seat at the board
22. IV.15— Friday.

Mr William Willis called upon me again this morning, and said Mr Brent of The Department of State had promised him to examine the files of the Department, for the papers which towards the close of President Washington’s Administration, Willis communicated respecting Canada— He brought me a model of mechanical invention of his own to accelerate the motion of Steamboats, with a model of his machine for turning the wheels without the operation of a Crank— Also a printed description with drawing of another invention of a rudder for Sailboats, so formed as to be capable to use to impel boats against the stream— In the efficacy of these inventions
he has himself undoubting confidence and says he has tried them upon a small Scale. He proposes to take out a Patent at least for the first of them in England. I called at the U.S. Branch bank, and executed two deeds—one as a Trustee of W. N. Boylston of 15 1/2 Acres of Land called Wachusett Meadow at Princeton; and the other a power of Attorney to my Son Charles to vote for me at any Meeting of the Boylston market Association— Mr S. H. Smith and B. L. Lear witnessed the Deeds and Smith took the acknowledgment of them— I wrote and enclosed them to my Son Charles— Paid a morning visit to Mr Vaughan the British Minister, who was not at home, and I left a card— Mr Frye, Mr Johnson, and Mrs. Smith dined with us, and Mr Smith was here in the Evening. My time slips away from me, so that I execute no useful resolution. The third Volume of Scott’s Bible begins with the Ecclesiastes, and two Chapters a day with his commentary, gives as much reading as ten chapters without it— His Commentary is not satisfactory to me— It explains nothing—it leads to no new ideas. I think this Song of Solomon ought not to have been included in the Canon— It is a beautiful Oriental irregular Pastoral drama— Solomon wrote a thousand Songs all of which but this one are lost. They were therefore not intended for holy writ—not inspiration— Nor do I believe it of this. The unnatural fancy that ever bore the name of criticism— It has no reference whatever to the Union of Christ and the Church— It is oriental poetry, luxurious and sentimental; tender, voluptuous and yet not unchaste— The description of Spring is exquisite—the dialogue though broken and desultory, pathetic; the imagery surprizing, and the moral remarkable as plainly disapproving Polygamy— I cannot endure Scott’s Commentary— I am still driving upon the Rhetorics to Herennius.
23. V:15. Saturday—

On my way back from my walk round the Capitol Square, I met Chief Justice Marshall, who is also a walker before Sun rise— He is my Senior by ten years or more and still enjoys health and vigour of mind, and body— Dr Condict, Member of the House of Representatives from New-Jersey, introduced Mr Frelinghuysen the new Senator from that State, said to be a man of great worth, Talent, and Eloquence. Dr Lovell introduced the Revd. Mr Campbell with whom I had some conversation upon the comparative numbers of the different religious denominations in this Country. He says that the Roman Catholics are making excessive efforts to procure proselytes, and with considerable success. In this City particularly the pretended miraculous recovery of Mrs Mattingly, five or six years since, from death’s door to perfect health by the prayers of Prince Hohenlohe; effected instantaneously, the Prince being in Germany, and his Patient in Washington City, has been followed by numerous conversions— Mr Campbell says sixty within the last year— I asked what had become very unaccountable in his alledged miraculous cures, no one of which was more remarkable; better attested, or more effective from the last Stage of disease to sound and perfect health, than that of Mrs Mattingly— Dr Lovell said he believed the Prince was dead. I wrote this Evening a Letter to Nathaniel Curtis; and enclosed to him Petty Vaughans Letter; with the abstract from the opinion of Mr Richmond— Yesterday and this day I have written each two pages of the Chapter upon the Russian and Turkish War; a subject that distresses me greatly, and for the effect of which I am over-solicitous.
24. V. Sunday— Sun rose 7.6.

Heard this morning Mr Lincoln, at the Unitarian Church from Galatians 6.5. “For every man shall bear his own burden.” The Gentlemen affords a striking example of the extreme importance of pronuntiation, to a public Speaker. He is in this particular very defective, and seems to have a special fondness for the words which he most cripples. He is also more emphatic in his manner than the substance of his discourses warrants— This is the last day of his preaching here— He is settled at Fitchburg Massachusetts— His sermons are sensible but there is nothing in them that stamps itself upon the memory— After the Service I paid a visit to Mr Richardson, at Mr Poor’s— He told me that Mr Frothingham of Boston was coming here next, to preach, and would be here next Sunday; unless he should stop for a fortnight at Philadelphia, and supply the place of Mr Furness who will the come here for two Sundays, and then be followed by Mr Frothingham. I called at Brown’s Hotel, and left Cards for each of the Seven Judges of the Supreme Court, none of them being at home. Next, visited Mr Webster at Dr Lindsly’s. Saw him and Mrs Webster and his daughter Julia. Mrs Webster is a daughter of Herman Le Roy, a very kind friend of mine at Amsterdam fifty years ago. Mr Webster was apparently so much occupied, that I made my visit short. I then called upon Mr J. W. Taylor and had much conversation with him— He read me a part of a Letter from Mr Clay, written in November in apparent very good Spirits; and he mentioned the wish of Mr Clay’s friends here that he should now be assumed and proclaimed by the friends of the last Administration as their Candidate for the next Presidential Election. Taylor himself is not inclined to this, and says that Clay has not and never had any party in New-York. But he thinks that the friends of the late Administration for want of a Leader would range themselves under Van Buren or Calhoun. I told him that I thought it would be fatal to the prospects of Mr Clay, if he should be just announced from this place, and that his first nomination should come from the West; and from his own State— He said he had heard that Mr Calhoun, was attempting to turn the anti-masonic tempest to his account, but I believed he would not make much of that— I said that I thought a new organization of parties with reference to the Presidency must take place. That questions will arise from the progress of this Administration, which would divide the Country— That in the discussion of these questions Mr Clay may very probably take a lead, which will bring him conspicuously before the Country. But that very probably—new men, not yet known, or thought of as Candidates may be started and brought forward. In the foreign Policy the Negotiations with England, and the project of taking Texas may raise such questions— The public Lands, the Indians, the overthrow of the Tariff, the putting down of the Navy, may produce them— There are combustibles enough; they only want kindling and the torches are at hand— He asked me if I thought the present administration would attempt to put down the Tariff— I thought they would; and that the apparent adhesion of their party to it now, was only to give it value in Negotiation with England. They would probably obtain the revocation of the British interdict upon our direct trade with their West-India Islands, and perhaps the Navigation of the St. Lawrence— The restoration of the West-India trade would force itself upon the British Government, by the sufferings of the Islands themselves; the Navigation of the St. Lawrence they would yield, because it would be for their own Interest, but they would chaffer for them because
they know the present Administration want to obtain them as party measures; and they will exact an equivalent for them; which can only be at the expense of the Tariff— Their only difficulty will be to obtain terms which two thirds of the Senate will ratify. Mr Taylor seemed surprized at these opinions, and thought there was no danger for the Tariff— He asked me why I thought there was a disposition to put down the Navy— I referred to the Message—to the Report of the Secretary of the Navy; and to the Proceedings now going on in Congress— I also expressed my opinions against the distribution to the States of the proceeds of the public Lands, and especially against the exclusion of the application of them to purposes of internal improvements— Upon some of these points Mr Taylor’s opinions differ essentially from mine— I set with him till he was called to dinner— In the Evening I heard Mr Campbell’s third and concluding Lecture upon the character of St. Paul from 2. Corinthians 11.22–27— There was an accompaniment to the singing, with an Harmonica—very soft and musical— Dr Lovell told me they were beginning to introduce this instrument into churches as a substitute for the Organ.
25. V. Monday.

Met Chief Justice Marshall again in my morning walk— Having finished reading Solomon’s Song with Scott’s Commentary, I took up this morning in the Bible without Commentary, the Apocryphal book of the Wisdom of Solomon— From the character of its contents it seems more worthy of a place among the Canonical Books than the Song— But the Style is different from that of any book of the Old Testament— There is a sequence in the Greek compositions, not apparent in the didactic Hebrew Books— The turn of mind, and modes of expression in the Book of Wisdom, seem to belong to a Later Age than the Proverbs, Ecclesiastes and Song. The Sententiousness is more peremptory and less argumentative in the Hebrew Books— I continue to read about one hour every morning in the works of Cicero— This day I finished the third and began upon the fourth Book of the Rhetorics to Herennius— This fourth book is upon Elocution, by which the author understands the composition of a discourse— It begins by a declaration that he will not imitate the example of the Greek Rhetoricians who borrow from others the illustrations of their precepts; but will invent them all himself; and he wastes a long argument to prove that a teacher of the Art should draw upon his own resources for his examples as well as for his precepts. The examples that he gives are very good, but they regard nothing but figures of speech and construction of Sentences. As a System of Rhetoric this is a very good work, and embraces within a very small compass the theory of the Art. Though very different from the Style of Cicero, it is more methodical and complete than any one of his Treatises, though in many parts of the first books it is almost the same with Cicero’s books de Inventione— It contains many very judicious precepts, some of which are not in Cicero— He points out clearly the distinction between the Solemn, the Neat and the familiar Style, and gives examples of each, well defined. He insists frequently on the absolute necessity of frequent practice to render any instruction effective, and he cautions against the frequent introduction of moral sentences; observing that when rare and judicious they are highly ornamental, and pleasing, but when thickly crowded they impress the hearer with the idea that the Speaker is employed as a teacher than in action. I was all the day very constantly engaged; wrote a Letter to my Son Charles, and made some progress in my Russian and Turkish War— Evening quite unwell with a Sore throat.
26. IV. Tuesday Sun Rose 7:

Feverish Night— A sore throat continually returning with cold weather, and broken rest— I rose at four O’Clock, and wrote a page of the Chapter upon the Turkish War before walking out— Met Chief Justice Marshall walking just as I was descending the Capitol Hill, on my return. He turned and walked with me till we came to the end of the Avenue. I had morning visits from the two brothers Tayloe—Edward has just returned from the Republic of Colombia, to which he went as Secretary of Legation with General Harrison; who has been recalled to provide a place for free Tom Moore— Also from Mr Vaughan the British Minister— I asked him what was the state of Negotiations among the European powers, respecting Greece— He did not know. Paragraphs in the Newspapers mention that the Turks had proposed the entire cession of Moldovia and Wallachia to Russia instead of the payment of money which they stipulated in the Treaty of Peace, and which they now find a difficulty in raising— I asked him what Government they were about giving to the Greeks, and why they had not left them to determine that themselves. He could not or did not incline to answer this; but I saw that he was strongly prejudiced against Count Capo d’Istrias; the present President of Greece, who he said was entirely under the influence of Russia— Mr T. B. Johnson was here this morning— I wrote a short Letter to Mr Benjamin Vaughan, and two more pages of the Chapter on the Russian and Turkish War.
27. VI. Wednesday.

There is an involuntary inequality in my hour of rising, which interferes much with regularity of occupation, and now distresses me— I took my walk this morning immediately after rising, and met and walked again with Chief Justice Marshall— My Sore throat and cold, which so incessantly returns upon me is troublesome and gives me interruption. Mr Beecher of New-Haven, brought me a Subscription-paper for an Abridgment of Noah Webster’s Quarto Dictionary to be published by a Mr Worcester—already a third Edition— I accordingly subscribed— I received from Joseph Blunt at New-York, a cover, enclosing the four sheets of manuscript which I had sent him on the 16th. to be copied— I finished the next four sheets and enclosed them to him with a Letter— I read the Wisdom of Solomon; and there find Chapter 8. v. 7. The following words— “And if a man love righteousness her labours are virtues: for she teacheth temperance, and prudence, justice, and fortitude: which are such things as man can have nothing more profitable in their life.”— Here are the four Cardinal Virtues of the Grecian Schools of philosophy which did not exist till five or six hundred years of the age of Solomon— My inference from which is that this book was a Grecian composition of a later date than Socrates and Plato— I read 15. Sections of the fourth book of the Rhetorics to Herennius, of which I think much better than I did formerly— I read a few pages of the horrible narratives of Pouqueville; and this day I received the English Quarterly Review for November 1829. which contains cheek by jowl Two Articles of vilification; one upon America and one upon Russia—one a Review of the Duke of Saxe-Weimar, and Captain Hall’s Travels—and the other of
several recent publications upon Turkey— They are both full of rancorous English passions; but I had not time to read them through— I received also this day the four Volumes lately published of T. Jefferson’s posthumous works.
28. IV. Thursday.

Though I rose this morning at four, I went out about ten minutes later than usual, and met Chief Justice Marshall twice, as he was going out and returning— A person named Tree, brought me from the Post Office a packet, torn open its whole width at the end, with a Letter from Thomas L. Noyes a Clerk in the Post-Office, stating that on assorting the Mail this morning, he had found it in that condition. It was from New-York, Postmarked the 25th. and contained the manuscript copy of the Chapter upon the War between Russia and Persia; made as I had requested Blunt that it should be made, upon sheets written only on one side of the leaf; upon seventeen sheets of Letter paper— I wrote to the Postmaster General, and enclosed to him the torn cover, for his information— I received also a Letter from J. B. Davis at Boston, enclosing a statement made by William Sawyer of Charlestown, before a magistrate, of the manner in which the Cunningham Correspondence was published— It was a dirty job between the Son of William Cunningham, Paul Willard, Jonathan Russell, Henshaw now Collector at Boston, and Green now the Postmaster. Sawyer advanced his money for the publication, and was finally left in the lurch by the associates— He wrote to Jonathan Russell last August, stating that the loss on the publication had been 500 dollars, and calling on him for his portion or one third of the contribution, but Russell did not answer his Letter. I received also a Letter from N. Curtis and Mrs Boylston with several enclosures, from J. Lowell and Petty Vaughan, much increasing the difficulty of acting correctly, in the affairs of Mr Boylston— My influenza Cold is oppressive upon the lungs, and I adhere with extreme difficulty to my various occupations— I finished reading the Rhetorics of Herennius and lament that I cannot now sum up my reflections upon the whole rhetorical works of Cicero as I had intended, for the benefit of my Son Charles. The Treatise addressed to Herennius is in a Style altogether different from that of Cicero; but pure and chaste and perfectly methodical. In the fourth book especially the rules of composition are judicious and interspersed with profound reflections, some of which are not in Cicero— One of the great excellences of this Treatise— It contains a complete System of Rhetoric which may be read attentively through in three hours— Finished reading the two Articles of the November English Quarterly Review on America, and on Turkey—and worked doggedly upon my Chapter of the Russian and Turkish War.
29. V. Friday.

The weather alternates warm and cold almost every other day. This morning was moderate— I met the Chief Justice— Received a Letter from my Son Charles and wrote to John B. Davis— The abuse of betraying private Correspondence is so great in this Country that it loses almost all its freedom— In writing Letters I cannot control my pen, and often after writing, perceive that much of what I have written is fit only to burn— I thought so of half my Letter this day to J. B. Davis, yet finally concluded to let it all go— It absorbed the morning; and the Turkish and Russian War the remainder of the day; excepting an hour of the morning to read 12 Letters of the first Book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus. I still read without
Dictionary, Commentary or Translation: a practice which I have adopted but lately and which I believe in one years practice, an hour every day would make the language more familiar than three years of Study, with Commentaries and Dictionaries and Dissertations— The Epistles have difficulties peculiar to themselves, among which there is a constant interspersion of Greek words, sentences and quotations. The Letters to Atticus commence a short time before the Consulate of Cicero— There should be a date affixed by the Commentators to each Letter, which there might be for most of them with little difficulty— Mr Gorham, Mr Bailey and William Lee were successively here in the Evening— Mr Gorham invited me to dine with him, and a small party of friends to-morrow, which invitation I accepted, though with a heavy cold upon me— John dined at Mr T. B. Johnson’s
30. V. Saturday.

The weather has turned again severely cold, and my walk this morning round the Capitol Square, was a sharper trial than I had experienced this Season— Mr Vance, member of the House of Representatives came and introduced a Mr M’Donald, of that State, and a young man named Thomson from South Carolina— I dined with Mr Gorham— Mrs Gorham and Miss Danforth were at table— The company were R. G. Amory, T. Burges, E. Everett, J. Read, P. Sprague, D. Webster, and W. Wirt the party was social and pleasant, but there was no very interesting Conversation. Amory was the most talkative: but he dwells too much upon the same topics, and his politics are diverting only because there is no motive for repeating what he says to injure him— I came home between 8 and 9. with Mr Wirt who lodges at my neighbour Mr Swann’s; and met my own Carriage on the way, going for me— Mr T. B. Johnson had dined here— I found my cold more oppressive, and was obliged to intermit writing and reading for the Evening. Read this morning several Letters to Atticus— The Account of the Trial of Clodius for his profanation of the mysteries pro populo at Caesar’s house is interesting— His acquittal by the venality of a major part of his judges—an enquiry into this iniquity instituted by the Senate and a consequent dissension between the two orders the Senate and the Knights, among whom the judges had been selected. He tells of some sharp and cutting repartees which passed between himself and Clodius. The 13th. 16th. and 17th Letters of this book, are studies for composition— Others are affecting by the passionate attachment disclosed in them for his Tusculanum; and his books. The delight with which he retires from the forum the Senate and the Bar, to meditation and philosophy— The 18th. Letter, in which he requests Atticus to return to Rome, that his friend may have someone with whom he may hold communion, of whom he may take counsel, with whom he may laugh without restraint and sigh with the freedom of the fire side is inimitably pathetic. In several of the Letters he Mentions a manuscript Commentary upon his own Consulate, which he had written in Greek. He speaks doubtfully of his Greek Style, which he requests his friend to criticise gently— There are some characters admirably drawn: and some exquisite strokes of Satire.
31. IV. Sunday— The coldest Morning of the Season

Heard at the Unitarian Church, this morning Mr Frothingham of Boston from Mark 6.20 “For Herod feared John, knowing that he was a just man, and an holy, and observed him; and when he heard him, he did many things, and heard him gladly.” The Sermon was a very ingenious and apposite commentary upon the text; analysing it in all its parts; and making it illustrative of the contrasted characters of Herod, and of John the Baptist— Mr Frothingham’s delivery was good, and the small auditory notwithstanding the severity of the weather listened to him with undivided attention— The evening was so cold, Fahrenheit at 22 that I did not venture from the House— I stopped at Church to speak to Mr Frothingham— He says that Mrs Brooks is very dangerously ill— I employed the Evening, in writing to my Son Charles’s wife— In the morning I began reading the Book of Ecclesiasticus, or Wisdom of the Son of Sirach, which I have always thought the most valuable of the Apocryphal books— It is avowedly of the age of the Ptolemy’s during the captivity; and has every appearance of being what it purports to be; which is not the character of the wisdom of Solomon— I finished also the first Book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus, and read the first Letter of the second Book— His ambition to imitate Demosthenes appears in a collection of his own Orations which he delivered while he was Consul which he therefore calls Consulares, and of which he sends a copy to his friend— The Letter upon the misunderstanding between his brother Quintus and Atticus is admirable. In others the strokes of Satire are pungent— The sketches of character, blasting—the deep sensibility to patriotism, to friendship, to the domestic affections to literature and taste delightful and instructive— I wandered over the pages of Sale’s Koran this day, to search the passages which command war against the infidels— The principal precept is in chapter 47. which Sale calls Mohammed; but which in a note he says some entitle War.

Day. I rise between four and six— Read three Chapters of the Bible— Walk round the Capitol Square 1 hour and 15 minutes—read Cicero one hour. Breakfast at nine. Read Newspapers Annual Registers Pouqueville, Sale’s Koran; other Books or Slips upon Turkey, receive visitors, and write Journal or Diary till four when we dine— Two hours from five to seven for the Siesta— Three, from seven till ten for writing— Bed— In the month I have written forty pages of Russian Wars with Persia and Turkey. My health is again precarious— Blessings yet abound—
